solution_line_template: First, we must recognize that all pairs of shoes and socks are actually {items_per_pair} items each, whereas the pants and the t-shirts are individual items. Therefore there are {initial_sock_pairs}*{items_per_pair}= <<{initial_sock_pairs}*{items_per_pair}={initial_individual_socks}>>{initial_individual_socks} individual socks in {initial_sock_pairs} pairs of socks.

Similarly, there are {initial_shoe_pairs}*{items_per_pair}=<<{initial_shoe_pairs}*{items_per_pair}={initial_individual_shoes}>>{initial_individual_shoes} individual shoes in {initial_shoe_pairs} pairs of shoes.

Therefore, Jonas has {initial_individual_socks}+{initial_individual_shoes}+{initial_pants}+{initial_tshirts}= <<{initial_individual_socks}+{initial_individual_shoes}+{initial_pants}+{initial_tshirts}={total_initial_items}>>{total_initial_items} individual items in his collection.
To double this number, we perform {total_initial_items}*{double_factor}=<<{total_initial_items}*{double_factor}={target_total_items}>>{target_total_items}.
This means we need {target_total_items}-{total_initial_items}=<<{target_total_items}-{total_initial_items}={new_items_needed}>>{new_items_needed} new items to double the size.

Since there are {items_per_pair} individual socks in each pair, we take {new_items_needed}/{items_per_pair}= <<{new_items_needed}/{items_per_pair}={new_sock_pairs_needed}>>{new_sock_pairs_needed} new pairs of socks.
